item.title: Syrians Face a Bread Shortage in Aleppo and Elsewhere
item.description: Since late November bread has been scarce, with a lack of fuel and flour shutting most bakeries in the Syrian city, creating problems for the new transitional council.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A bakery in Aleppo. The price has shot up from 15 Syrian pounds, about 21 cents, for a bag of about eight flat, pitalike loaves to more than 200 pounds, nearly $3.

item.title: Syrian Airstrike Kills Palestinian Refugees
item.description: Government forces killed at least eight people in the Yarmouk district of Damascus and reportedly drove dozens of formerly pro-government Palestinian fighters to defect to the rebels.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By AN EMPLOYEE OF THE NEW YORK TIMES and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: China Plans on Continuity in Economic Policy in 2013
item.description: An annual conference that helps set economic policy ended with the government warning about difficulties in the global economy, but suggesting few policy changes.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: In Europe, a Push for Higher Phone Fees
item.description: Phone bills could rise if a European Union plan to encourage spending on high-speed broadband networks is enacted.
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN J. O’BRIEN

item.title: Liberal Democratic Party Returns to Power in Japan
item.description: The Liberal Democratic Party was returned to power in parliamentary elections Sunday in what analysts say is more a vote against the incumbents than a mandate.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Shinzo Abe, the former prime minister, whose Liberal Democratic Party regained control of Parliament for the first time in three years.

item.title: The Hard Road Back: Chaplain with Traumatic Brain Injuries, Finds Tables Turned
item.description: For Lt. Col. Richard Brunk, a former Army chaplain, two instances of traumatic brain injury from blasts in Iraq have tugged away at a mask of good cheer.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JAMES DAO
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Richard Brunk joined the ministry and then the military, which sent him to Iraq. Two explosions there left him with traumatic brain injury.

item.title: Egypt Votes on Constitution; Muslim Brotherhood Expects Approval
item.description: Preliminary tallies in Egypt showed a relatively narrow margin of victory for the charter so far, with about 33 percent turnout and orderly balloting after weeks of violence and threats of boycott.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling site in Cairo on Saturday. Lines were long as a referendum on an Islamist-backed charter got off to an orderly start.

item.title: Letter From Washington: U.S. Fiscal Deal Unlikely Without Compromise
item.description: As the political tension mounts over Washington's fiscal deadlock, there will have to be trade-offs from Democrats and Republicans for any deficit-reduction pact to happen.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG NEWS

item.title: Abdessalam Yassine, Leader of Moroccan Opposition Movement, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Yassine was the charismatic religious leader of Morocco’s largest opposition movement and a longtime opponent of two Moroccan kings.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 15
item.description: Horror in Connecticut; Japan's political pendulum; a year of British wonders in sports; Europe backs common banking rules.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Why Does the N.R.A. Oppose the Global Arms Trade Treaty?
item.description: The Connecticut school massacre has spurred calls for implementing the proposed global arms trade treaty, even though its proponents say the agreement would not cover domestic U.S. sales. The American gun lobby disagrees.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Memorial candles near the scene of the Newtown, Connecticut shooting on Saturday.

item.title: Egyptians Turn Out for Referendum Vote
item.description: Egyptians voted on an Islamist-backed draft constitution, hoping that the results would end three weeks of violence and division.

item.title: Voters in Egypt Cast Ballots on Draft Constitution
item.description: The main group aligned with President Mohamed Morsi predicted ratification of a constitutional referendum after Egyptians voted peacefully and in large numbers.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling site in Cairo on Saturday. Lines were long as a referendum on an Islamist-backed charter got off to an orderly start.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: China Calls for 'No Delay' on Gun Controls in U.S.
item.description: China, which enforces a near-total ban on the private possession of firearms, has called for stricter gun controls in the United States. On the same day that a gunman killed 20 first-graders and six women at a school in Connecticut, a man in China stabbed 22 children and an 85-year-old woman. There were no fatalities in that attack, although some of the children reportedly had their ears and fingers cut off.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MCDONALD
item.media:description: The flag on the White House was at half-staff after the school shootings in Connecticut. The Washington Monument is in the background.

item.title: Gustavo Archilla, Whose Wedding Inspired Gay-Marriage Advocates, Dies at 96
item.description: Mr. Archilla and his partner, Elmer Lokkins, lived together in Manhattan for 58 years before eloping to Canada in 2003 and coming out publicly.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Gustavo Archilla, right, and Elmer Lokkins met in Columbus Circle in New York in 1945 and married in Canada in 2003.

item.title: Foreign Minister Blames Sanctions for Syria’s Troubles
item.description: Walid al-Moallem called on the United Nations to push for lifting the measure as government forces continued air and artillery strikes in the Damascus suburbs.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and C. J. CHIVERS

item.title: Despite Threat of Steep Fines, Protesters Turn Out in Moscow
item.description: Antigovernment demonstrators in Russia were met by a huge contingent of police officers, and prominent opposition leaders were arrested during the rally Saturday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aleksei Navalny, an opposition leader, was arrested seconds after this photograph was taken at Lubyanka Square in Moscow.

item.title: Militants’ Attack on Airport Leaves 7 Dead in Pakistan
item.description: The assault began when militants fired two rockets that punched a hole in the airport perimeter wall, wounding at least 40.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: China Steps Up Pressure On Japan in Island Dispute
item.description: Analysts say China has fixed upon a strategy to take back the islands known as Diaoyu in China and the Senkaku in Japan, by using air and naval patrols as evidence that they are in charge.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: 18 Men Drown Trying to Reach Greece
item.description: The immigrants were coming from Turkey, and rescuers were seeking nine other people, though there were no details about their ethnic origins.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Mandela Has Surgery to Remove Gallstones
item.description: Nelson Mandela, the former president of South Africa who is now 94, had a successful endoscopic procedure, the government said.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Hillary Clinton Suffers a Concussion After Fainting
item.description: Because of a stomach virus, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton suffered a concussion early last week after fainting and striking her head, the State Department said.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton fainted and struck her head last week.

item.title: As Gold Is Spirited Out of Afghanistan, Officials Wonder Why
item.description: Officials have said the “obvious suspicion” is that at least some of the apparent growth in gold shipments to Dubai is tied to illicit activities that have come to define Afghanistan’s economy.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Zalmai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Kabul jewelry shop. Officials are concerned about gold being flown out of Afghanistan.

item.title: In Brazil, Caves Would Be Lost in Mining Project
item.description: A mining company is proceeding with a project that could help revive Brazil’s economy, but it would also destroy caves treasured by scholars of Amazonian prehistoric human history.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: A speleologist from Vale, the Brazilian mining giant, in October at a cave in the Carajás Mountains, where it plans to expand an iron-ore mining complex.

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
item.description: Best of long-form journalism this week.
item.dc:creator: By ANJANI TRIVEDI
